measured_by: discounting score (0–19) derived from binary choice items
justification: “All data were collected … with a 30-item instrument developed specifically for assessing a base discounting level…  Finally, we computed a discounting score based on responses to all choice items, which ranged from 0 … to 19.”

measured_by: binary choice scenarios varying reward size within the intertemporal choice instrument
justification: The Measurement section defines Absolute magnitude as “Increased preference for delayed gains when values become substantially larger… (e.g., prefer $500 now… and prefer $5500 in 12 months…).”

measured_by: binary gain vs. loss choice scenarios in the intertemporal choice instrument
justification: Gain-loss asymmetry is described and operationalised: “Gains are discounted more than losses… (e.g., prefer to receive $500 now… but also prefer to pay $500 now…).”

measured_by: binary choice scenarios framed as delay versus speed-up within the instrument
justification: Delay-speedup asymmetry is measured by choices “Accepting an immediate, smaller gain if the delay is framed as added value, but preferring the larger, later amount if an immediate gain is framed as a reduction…”.

measured_by: binary choice scenarios comparing 0–12-month vs. 12–24-month intervals
justification: Present bias is defined and measured where participants “prefer $500 now over $550 in 12 months and prefer $550 in two years over $500 in 12 months,” i.e., shifting the start of the interval.

measured_by: three-interval (0-12, 12-24, 0-24 months) choice scenarios in the instrument
justification: “We also assess subadditivity effects… allowing us to assess discounting over three time intervals… Subadditivity is considered present if discounting is higher for the two 12-month intervals compared to the 24-month interval.”
